Jacob Singer.Action: Responds to teasing with quick wit and confidence, maintaining composure among peers.
Engages in lighthearted banter and mock gestures rather than showing leadership or tactical awareness in a combat situation.
Grabs convulsing George and shoves a rifle barrel between his teeth to stop him from choking.
Jumps on top of Frank to wrestle him into the grass and restrain him during his violent panic.
Stares at Frank’s face showing concern and recognition of his suffering rather than abandoning him.
Remains alone with Frank when others flee in panic, asking Paul 'Don't leave me.'
Grabs George and uses a rifle barrel to prevent him from biting his tongue during convulsions.
Jumps on top of Frank and wrestles him to the ground to subdue his violent outburst.
Remains alone with a dangerous and panicked Frank while others flee, showing presence of mind and bravery.
Struggles to restrain Frank despite the chaos, enduring pain silently.
Sits alone on the subway, absorbed in reading Camus, detached from surroundings.
Attempts to restrain FRANK who is struggling like four men, showing physical effort and endurance.
Becomes physically wounded—hit in the back and stabbed in the stomach—indicating a failure to protect himself effectively in combat.
Wakes up dazed and confused in a strange environment, unsure of his surroundings initially.
Calmly pulls out a book and begins reading to compose himself, showing presence of mind and intellectual engagement despite confusion.
Is described as a good-looking man of obvious intelligence, suggesting an underlying intellectual competence.
His restlessness and concern on the interminable subway ride suggest internal anxiety and possible inability to resolve his situation comfortably.
Motions to a woman for help with the stuck door, tries to ask a simple question politely.
Shows a look of disgust and kicks the stuck door in frustration.
Responds with a slightly sarcastic remark 'Yeah, you and everyone else' when the woman answers.
Sits quietly and waits after receiving minimal interaction from others in the train car.
Stands up and tries to move through the subway cars to find information despite difficult conditions and a stuck door.
Tries to get help from a woman who is clearly unwilling to assist him.
Becomes visibly frustrated and kicks the stuck door to open it.
Asks clear and direct questions to the woman to determine their location.
Sits down after failing to get cooperation and waits until he can see the station signs to confirm location.
Observes the old man carefully and notes unusual details, showing alertness and attention to detail.
Notices the fearful expression of the lady on the train before it departs.
Groans in frustration at being trapped, but does not take out his anger on others.
Proceeds cautiously and with care despite discomfort and fear to find a way out.
Notices locked gates, assesses situation, tries to find an exit.
Cautiously climbs down ladder to tracks despite fear.
Struggles to see, steps into unseen liquid and grime, showing lack of preparation.
Panics when train approaches, uncertain which way to go.
Makes a quick decision to jump across the track, narrowly escaping harm.
Responds to muffled screams and investigates despite potential danger.
Breaks the locked gate in anger after witnessing violence and apparent abuse.
Stands silently, uncertain when hearing whispering and noises, showing hesitation but concern.
Regains composure after near panic and continues moving forward despite confusion and fear.
Approaches suspicious situation cautiously, knocks softly before investigating.
Hesitates and is unsure how to respond to the scream and moaning behind the door.
Allows himself to be trapped quickly when door is slammed and locked with a knife threat.
Responds to being trapped by breaking the chained gate with anger and force.
Storms the gate and forcibly breaks the chain to open it.
Pushes the gate open and shuts it forcefully, demonstrating physical assertiveness and decisiveness.
Uses three keys skillfully to unlock the door to his apartment.
Enters the dark apartment without turning on the light, attempts to navigate to the bathroom relying on minimal light, but fails and bangs into a table.
Engages in a brief, slightly confused verbal exchange about the room layout and moving furniture, indicating some disorientation.
Thanks Jezzie politely despite being tired and disheveled.
Avoids explaining the grease on his uniform and his condition to Jezzie, dismissing questions with short answers.
Allows Jezzie to touch him and share intimacy despite his discomfort.
Calls for help in the jungle when injured and alone.
Thanks Jezzie when she brings him his glasses and a paper bag.
Corrects Jezzie patiently about the Biblical origin of his children's names.
Expresses frustration with his poor eyesight and difficulty finding glasses.
Engages playfully and somewhat critically with Jezzie, calling her a 'heathen' and 'ninny'.
Shows genuine delight and interest in old family photographs, reminiscing positively.
Dismisses Jezzie's harsh characterization of his wife, somewhat lovingly defending her.
Becomes tearful unexpectedly when looking at a photo of his deceased son Gabe, showing deep emotional vulnerability and sincerity.
Carefully keeps a photo of his deceased son with photos of his other children, showing tenderness and care.
Insists on continuing to look at old family photos despite Jezzie's discomfort, showing a desire for connection to his past and family.
Hides his emotions quickly after becoming upset by photos of his deceased son, shows some control by putting the photo away carefully with others.
Becomes unexpectedly emotional and tears up, is momentarily unable to speak.
Thoughtfully looks through old photos and reflects on his life and family, showing introspection and awareness.
Asks Jezzie not to put away pictures because he wants to continue looking despite emotional difficulty.
Driving a mail truck skillfully through crowded midtown Manhattan while humming.
Effortfully lifting a stack of heavy boxes and closing the truck door with his foot.
Attempts to close the truck door but stops after it doesn't close properly due to heavy boxes instead of forcing it.
Opening the laundry and interacting with a woman who shows frustration about space management.
Reluctantly carries heavy boxes to the back room despite physical discomfort.
Engages in casual friendly conversation with the woman, compliments her tan genuinely.
Takes care to correct the paperwork politely without causing a scene.
Smiles to himself, showing a quiet, good-natured demeanor despite his back pain.
Reluctantly carries heavy boxes despite back pain, manages signatures and handles paperwork correctly.
Winces and shows signs of physical struggle but continues working; reacts to unexpected situation in mail truck with surprise and jump back.
Lifts the wino up and firmly tells him he cannot stay in the truck (government property).
Escorts the frightened wino off the truck and gives him a dollar out of kindness.
Returns to truck shaking his head, showing mild frustration or impatience.
Offers french fries to several coworkers who eagerly grab them.
Responds to Jezzie's hug with a gentle warning about his back but does not push her away.
Shrugs off potential conflict with his boss about leaving early and does not argue.
Offers his french fries around to coworkers, showing friendly social interaction but no clear indication of competence.
Expresses uncertainty about his back pain and his plan to see Louis, showing indecision or lack of proactive problem solving.
Shrugs off potential issues at work and seems passive about the boss's likely reaction to leaving early.
Communicates clearly and wittily with Jezzie, maintaining friendly rapport despite discomfort.
In chiropractic office, cooperates with chiropractor despite discomfort, shows some resilience.
Expresses concern about not paying alimony and ongoing orthodontist expenses for his children.
Denies or is defensive about Sarah's negative feelings toward him despite evidence.
Does not remember the difference between right and left, jokes about missing school.
Responds to Louis's instructions with confusion but attempts to follow along.
Mentions financial responsibility such as orthodontist payments despite alimony issues.
Denies the possibility that Sarah loves him despite evidence and Louis's interpretation.
Admits he feels unable to relax and shows vulnerability about his mental state post-war.
Light-heartedly compliments Louis by calling him an angel and cherub.
Spent eight years getting a PhD, showing academic dedication.
Chose to work at the post office after the war, seemingly giving up on using his intellectual skills.
Expresses inability to relax and cope with chaos, showing some mental fatigue or lack of resilience.
Engages in banter and follows Louis's instructions despite his discomfort, showing some trust and openness to help.
Experiences strange flashes, suggestive of internal psychological or neurological issues, indicating reduced mental control or awareness.
Joins the street gang's singing despite their taunts, creating a sweet moment.
Yells and waves his fist at men in the car who mock him after nearly hitting him.
Turns to thank the young man whose scream had saved him.
Lies silently in bed with Jezzie, showing a mournful and troubled demeanor but not engaging in conversation.
Annoyed and dismissive of Jezzie's attempts to connect his trauma and current experiences.
Turns to thank the young man whose scream saved him.
Lies in bed, staring mournfully at the ceiling, showing emotional distress but not taking active steps to address his issues.
Engages in a reflective conversation with Jezzie, questioning and trying to rationalize the strange events around him.
Is annoyed and dismissive when Jezzie suggests the war might explain his problems, showing resistance to insight.
Does not answer Jezzie's question about love, remains silent and turns away.
Stares out the window silently, does not engage in conversation with Jezzie about apocalyptic news.
Clearly states that people tried to kill him tonight and perceives the attackers as not human, showing heightened awareness of danger.
Does not respond to Jezzie's attempts at conversation or emotional engagement, including a direct question about love.
Silently stares out the window and does not engage with Jezzie's remarks or questions about dramatic world events and strange news.
Sits silently, disinterested when Jezzie attempts intimacy.
Turns to Jezzie and strokes her hair after realizing she is crying.
Nods 'yes' when Jezzie asks if he loves her, offering some reassurance.
Sits silently and disinterested, does not respond to Jezzie's advances or angry outburst.
Watches the courtyard's early morning movement in detail, noticing tiny figures drifting purposefully.
Responds to Jezzie's emotional breakdown by stroking her hair and nodding to affirm his love, showing emotional sensitivity but limited verbal communication.
Nods heavily in response to Jezzie's repeated question about love, indicating exhaustion or mental disengagement.
Speaks nervously and insists politely but firmly to see Dr. Carlson despite receptionist's refusal.
Uses some frustrated language ('Damn it', 'I'm going out of my fucking mind here') but remains focused on his need for help.
Attempts to see Dr. Carlson despite lack of appointment, persistently advocates for himself in a difficult situation.
Speaks nervously and aggressively to the receptionist, fails to secure a meeting or provide clear proof of his presence in the system.
Pounds the desk in anger and disrupts the receptionist causing her distress.
Backs away in fear when noticing the receptionist’s horns, then runs without calming the situation.
Charges through the corridors, unintentionally frightening mental patients and causing a scene.
Seeks out Dr. Carlson urgently, appears sincere and vulnerable upon learning of his death.
Refuses to fill out forms, pounds the desk aggressively, freaks out upon seeing the receptionist's horns and runs wildly through corridors trying to find Dr. Carlson.
Knows to seek out Dr. Carlson specifically, locates the group room quickly after running through corridors.
Ignorant of Dr. Carlson's death until told, appears stunned and unprepared for the news.
Pulls away when the leader tries to comfort him after news of Carlson’s death.
Refuses further help or intervention after hearing about Carlson’s death, saying 'I’m okay.'
Does not look back when being escorted out by policeman, avoiding confrontation or engagement.
Pulls away from the Leader's comforting gesture, indicating emotional self-control and decisiveness to maintain distance.
Refuses the Leader's offer to get help and insists he is okay despite being frightened and confused.
Quickly backs to the door and leaves the group when he feels overwhelmed, showing a lack of confidence or inability to manage the situation calmly.
Follows policeman’s instruction without resistance and does not look back, showing compliance and awareness of danger.
Shrugs off Elsa's palm reading and declines to engage, ignoring Jezzie trying to get his attention.
Shrugs off social invitations and ignores others' attempts to engage him (e.g., refuses palm reading, ignores Jezzie).
Observes and examines the birdcage carefully, reacting appropriately to the noise.
Understands the unusual attributes of his palm and responds with humor and some insight.
Does not engage with others' explanations about the joke, possibly indicating lack of understanding or social disconnect.
Relents to dancers' pressure and nods apologetically to Elsa, showing embarrassment and discomfort but ultimately not causing conflict.
Pulls away from Jezzie’s reach and grows distant and withdrawn during her taunting, showing avoidance rather than friendliness or engagement.
Tries to smile despite discomfort; attempts to adhere to social interaction though pained and unconvincing.
Does not retaliate or respond aggressively to Jezzie’s mockery and the dancers’ laughter, instead withdraws.
Looks away and becomes uncomfortable when witnessing shocking and disturbing scenes, unable or unwilling to intervene.
Relents to peer pressure and shows embarrassment at dancing inadequacy.
Attempts to maintain composure with a pained, unconvincing smile despite discomfort.
Grows distant and withdrawn emotionally in response to taunting, though physically continues to dance.
Withdraws and looks away uncomfortably when alone after others leave him.
Approaches a frightening, tortured image despite clear fear and shock.
Grabs his eyes trying to pull the vision from his head but cannot control it; his actions become spastic and delirious.
His frenzy becomes a kind of exorcism, a desperate attempt to free himself from his body and mind.
Despite the chaotic internal experience, he endures the ordeal until the music and vision end.
After dancing skillfully, he suddenly becomes frightened and paranoid, repeatedly asking where he is and showing confusion about his surroundings.
Attempts to assert control by demanding to see Della and questioning those around him despite his obvious distress.
His physical deterioration and paranoia undermine his ability to behave logically and confidently in a social situation.
Reacts with intense fear and rejection when others try to help him during his convulsive episode, screaming for them to stay away.
Refuses assistance and isolates himself despite obvious distress and concern from others.
Reacts to his convulsive shaking and burning up by screaming, recoiling from help, and expressing intense rage and fear, showing loss of control and inability to manage situation.
Attempts to communicate inability to stop his shaking ('If I could stop it, I'd stop it.'), demonstrating some awareness of his condition.
Calls after Jezzie to ask about his fever, shows concern about his health.
Complies hesitantly with Jezzie's urging despite confusion and discomfort, allowing her to care for him.
Responds to health emergency by following Jezzie's instructions despite confusion and physical distress.
Shows confusion and hesitation when told to get into a cold tub despite severe fever.
Does not question or resist medical advice that might be life-saving, showing trust in others' expertise.
Initially resists putting his foot in the ice water despite Jezzie's urging, showing fear and hesitation.
Relents to Jezzie's insistence and puts his foot in the icy water, enduring pain.
Hesitates and resists getting into the ice water, expresses fear and physical discomfort, avoids facing the painful treatment immediately.
Eventually puts his foot fully into the ice water despite the pain, endures the difficult treatment for as long as he can.
Rubs his foot vigorously to mitigate pain, attempts to manage his discomfort actively.
Expresses doubt and verbalizes incapacity ('I can't do it'), showing internal struggle to follow through with the necessary treatment.
Struggles and pleads to be released, cries out for help while being forced into the water, expressing clear distress and vulnerability.
Complains about cold air but considers Sarah's comfort and insists on closing the window for health reasons.
Yells suddenly and irritably during ice pouring scene.
Shares about his dream and engages Sarah in conversation, showing openness.
Stops Sarah from tucking Gabe in and carries Gabe himself, playfully tickling him and making him laugh.
Responds curtly to Gabe telling his mother it's cold with 'Tell your mother.'
Responds to his son's disturbance promptly and takes responsibility to comfort him by carrying him to bed and caring for him.
Gives a brief, somewhat dismissive answer to his son's question about the noise ('It was the window').
Appears surprised by his son's presence and unsure initially about what he is doing there.
Responds to his sons' late-night requests patiently, kisses one son, smiles warmly at expressions of love, hugs another tenderly and adjusts the door as requested to comfort him.
Tells Jed to wait until breakfast to get allowance despite it being early morning, gently but firmly setting boundaries.
Expresses love quietly to Sarah before sleeping, indicating sincere affection.

Handles his children's needs patiently and tenderly in the middle of the night, balancing firmness and warmth, and thoughtfully accommodates Gabe's request to leave the door ajar to help him feel secure.
Struggles internally with feelings of sadness and longing when lying awake, showing emotional vulnerability but no clear action to address it.
Stares at Jezzie and Mrs. Carmichael in total confusion while in the bathroom with the doctor and friends.
Stares in total confusion at people around him (Jezzie, Mrs. Carmichael, doctor), appearing disoriented and unsure.
Jacob reaches out for help and accepts care from Jezzie after nearly drowning.
Jacob appears lost and confused, silently watching Jezzie leave without interacting further.
Struggles physically after being pulled from icy water, collapses immediately, appears confused and disoriented.
Talks repeatedly to imagined or dead figures, exhibits confusion about location and situation.
Shows awareness of surroundings by watching Jezzie leave, attempts to comprehend his condition despite confusion.
Ignores Jezzie's attempts to engage him, focusing solely on his books despite her visible frustration.
Does not respond verbally or emotionally to Jezzie's anger and attempts to communicate.
Responds with affection to Jezzie's anger and playful gestures, expressing admiration and warmth towards her.
Smiles gently at Jezzie's clumsy struggle with her jacket and pocket change, showing patience and good-naturedness.
Remains affectionate and composed despite Jezzie's intense anger and chaos around him, showing emotional steadiness and attentiveness.
Smiles at Jezzie's clumsiness in putting on her coat, showing calm and lightheartedness in a stressful moment.
Takes the initiative to answer the telephone after Jezzie leaves the room, demonstrating attentiveness and promptness.
Does not intervene or attempt to calm Jezzie's rage actively, instead passively enduring the chaos, indicating some possible passivity or lack of assertiveness.
Greets old friend Paul warmly, expresses genuine surprise and pleasure at reconnecting.
Pats Paul on the back and compliments him sincerely.
Shows empathy discussing struggles of vets and the hardships Paul faces.
Initiates friendly conversation with Paul, recognizes him promptly, and engages warmly despite being sick and laid up.
Acknowledges his sickness openly and honestly to Paul, showing self-awareness.
Does not immediately question why Paul needs to see him, accepts the meeting without hesitation.
Shows empathy toward Paul's situation and comments insightfully on the difficulties veterans face when trying to find work.
Listens attentively to Paul expressing distress and acknowledges his concerns, nodding silently.
Questions Paul's safety and troubles, showing concern about the car following them and Paul's shaking arm.
Questions why they are driving in a nerve-wracking area, implying care about their safety.
Listens quietly and attentively to Paul's terrified confessions without judgment or interruption.
Despite witnessing Paul's obvious distress and need for support, does not follow him or offer immediate comfort after Paul abruptly leaves the booth.
Holds back his fear despite tense situation, listens attentively to Paul's distress
Does not follow Paul when he suddenly walks away despite apparent urgency
Puts his arm around Paul and holds him tightly, offering comfort as best he can when Paul is terrified.
Reassures Paul gently, telling him 'It's okay' and sharing that he has experienced similar torment.
Moves quickly to comfort Paul during his panic attack, offers calm reassurance, and helps him relax.
Shares his own experience of seeing the demons, showing understanding and empathy.
Invites Paul to come home with him, offering support in a fearful moment.
Makes a joking comment about his girlfriend’s cousins breeding, lightening the mood.
Leans back quietly, appears distracted or withdrawn while Paul talks about fears.
Leans back and thinks deeply, showing active mental engagement and problem consideration.
Invites Paul to come home with him to provide support and safety, showing practical problem-solving and social awareness.
Makes a joking comment about girlfriend's cousins to ease tension, showing social confidence and emotional intelligence.
Expresses uncertainty repeatedly ('I don't know. I don't know.') when confronted with confusing or frightening information.
Distracted by noticing a dime on the sidewalk and bending to pick it up shortly before Paul's car begins to move (potentially dangerous moment).
Screams for help and shows vulnerability when injured in the helicopter.
Relies on and trusts the young man from the bar who helps him after the explosion.
Looks for the young man who helped him after the explosion, showing appreciation and concern.
Sprawls flat on the ground and covers his head when the car explodes.
Screams over the roar of the helicopter for help and communicates urgency to the medics.
Struggles to understand his surroundings and identity after being rescued by the young man.
Looks for the young man who helped him despite the chaos.
Reaches across the seat to hold Jezzie's hand, showing vulnerability and seeking comfort.
Joins other veterans as pallbearer, supporting family and friends during a funeral.
Drinks beer with old army buddies, appears tired and defeated but participates in group mourning.
Shares Paul's fears and strange behavior honestly with the group, showing concern for Paul's state of mind.
Communicates clearly about Paul's disturbed mental state and recounts details accurately to the group despite the unsettling content.
Does not intervene or provide solutions to help Paul or the group cope with the distressing information.
Admits to having seen the strange phenomena and acknowledges others' experiences, sharing in their concerns.
Brings up the deaths of others to underline the seriousness of the situation, showing concern for group safety.
Admits to seeing the strange phenomena, corroborates others' experiences, and brings up evidence about Dr. Carlson's death to highlight a pattern, showing awareness and attempts at connecting dots.
Acknowledges the group's shared distress and proposes collective action to confront the army.
Invites others to join in seeking answers and suggests hiring a lawyer, showing inclusiveness and concern.
Dismisses Rod's reluctance, pushing forward despite a friend’s refusal to join.
Recognizes a pattern connecting recent violent incidents and proposes proactive investigation despite skepticism.
Suggests confronting the army and getting a lawyer as a strategic response to danger.
Persists in rallying others to investigate the threats despite dissent and potential ridicule.
Acknowledges others' doubts and considers collaborative action ('six heads better than one').
Advocates persistently for his group despite bureaucratic dismissal, showing determination and concern.
Engages respectfully with a skeptical lawyer, maintaining focus on the group's needs.
Admits to being 'too messed up to teach' in a self-deprecating and sincere way.
Shares an exuberant, affectionate, and playful intimate moment with Jezzie, showing openness and emotional warmth.
Expresses love sincerely to Jezzie and shares his honest feelings about his trauma.
Laughs and plays with Jezzie after being scared by her, showing easy camaraderie and affection.
Does not show any negative reaction in the excerpt to bad news (lawyer not taking case), but is stunned and silent rather than hostile or dismissive.
Expresses frustration and confusion about friends backing down, insists something must be exposed.
Responds angrily to Frank's vague and evasive answers.
Persists in trying to understand and help others despite their refusal and silence.
Expresses frustration and anger at Frank for giving up and hanging up abruptly.
Carefully handles old letters and memorabilia of comrades, showing sentiment and respect.
Runs alongside his son Gabe, supporting him as he learns to ride a bicycle and shares a genuine, warm moment of pride and joy.
Chases his lawyer and tries to engage him urgently about his problems, showing vulnerability and seeking help.
Grabs the back of Geary's jacket to stop him, which could be seen as aggressive and intrusive.
Persistently tries to communicate and connect with Geary despite rejection, indicating sincerity and emotional openness.
Rages at Geary for disbelieving him, physically assaults him by knocking over his soda can and sandwich, then shows satisfaction after humiliating him.
Demands investigation into his claim despite initial disbelief and pushes others to verify his story.
Becomes enraged and physically lashes out at Geary when confronted with contradictory information.
Fails to maintain composure or respond calmly to discrediting evidence, resorting to destructive actions.
Persists in asserting the truth of his experience despite others doubting him.
Tries to get away when soldiers approach him unexpectedly.
Goes berserk, howling and thrashing violently when confronted by officials.
Fights back aggressively when threatened with a gun, attempts to escape and protect himself.
Reaches out to passersby for help while in pain but is ignored by others.
Mentions his son's picture in stolen wallet with some sentimentality.
Sees gun in the car and immediately reacts violently, kicking to disable assailants and create an opportunity to escape.
Throws himself out of the car door amidst chaos and escape attempt, displaying quick thinking and physical resolve.
After injury, tries to get help by reaching out to passersby despite intense pain, showing persistence and presence of mind.
Refers to chiropractor and focuses on his injury symptoms clearly when in hospital, showing awareness of his condition.
Does not know who stole his wallet but provides information about personal items lost, showing honesty and clarity despite stress.
Insists on calling his chiropractor Louis Schwartz despite medical staff recommendations.
Tries to get up and questions where he is, showing fear and vulnerability.
Refuses to be moved by the resident, despite pain, showing assertiveness but potential distrust.
Insists on calling his chiropractor Louis Schwartz, showing knowledge of who can help him and attempts to direct care.
Refuses to be moved by medical resident despite instructions, indicating awareness of his body and caution.
Attempts to get up from the gurney despite severe pain and injury.
Is panicked and disoriented during transport, unable to fully comprehend his situation or location.
Cries out and screams in terror when confronted by nightmarish figures and pain.
Calls out 'Jezzie!' showing recognition and concern despite her being part of tormentors.
Pleading for help: 'Get me out of here...'
Cries out and screams showing immediate fear and horror upon seeing terrifying images.
Tries to sit up and scream despite pain and paralysis but fails to move or produce sound.
Expresses desperation and pleads for help when restrained by chained devices and surrounded by hostile figures.
Desperately pleads to be taken home and expresses denial over his death, showing vulnerability and a sincere desire for normalcy.
Responds with confusion and struggle, indicating a troubled but genuine internal state rather than hostility or coldness.
Rejects the Doctor's assertion that he is dead and insists on his own reality, showing persistence but also frustration rather than warmth or coldness.
Denies being dead and insists he is alive despite contradictory evidence, showing confusion and desperation.
Struggles and tries to resist the 'doctor' when confronted with his reality.
Expresses inability to understand his situation and fails to accept reality.
Expresses urgent desire to see and be with his family despite his pain and confusion.
Responds to family's presence with weak but sincere acknowledgment ('I'm not dead') showing connection and awareness.
Raves incoherently and shows confusion, delusional about his condition.
Despite pain and confusion, asserts 'I'm not dead' showing some mental presence and will.
Does not engage meaningfully with visitors or respond clearly to family's presence due to being doped up and injured.
Pleading desperately for help and showing vulnerability to Sarah.
Insisting on the presence of his family to the nurse, showing trust and transparency.
Ignoring or refusing to acknowledge the nurse's amused reaction to his belief in visitors, showing some distrust or frustration.
Asks clear, direct questions to the nurse about his condition and presence of family, showing alertness and awareness despite difficult circumstances.
Pleads helplessly for rescue ('Save me!'), appears confused and desperate.
Insists firmly that his experiences with visitors were real, demonstrating conviction and an attempt to assert reality.
Reacting emotionally and possibly irrationally to the nurse's teasing and smiles, turning away from perceived mockery.
Calls out to Louis urgently and shows recognition and relief at his arrival.
Allows Louis to intervene and be present during his medical distress without resistance.
Expresses vulnerability and fear about dying, admits having been in 'Hell' and not wanting to die.
Follows Louis's instructions despite pain and discomfort, cooperates fully.
Leans passively on the adjusting table, barely responds or takes control of the situation, shows vulnerability and suffering.
Asks thoughtful questions about death and the afterlife, indicating some introspection and self-awareness.
Attempts to stand and walk cautiously after therapy, showing persistence and trust in Louis's encouragement.
Turns abruptly and heads toward the door without acknowledging Louis’s supportive gesture.
Tells Louis 'I love you' firmly before leaving despite Louis's concern.
Pours gasoline and prepares to set fire on Army recruiting headquarters, yelling angrily at onlookers and cameras.
Despite physical weakness, insists on acting according to his conviction and takes decisive action by going to the Army Recruiting Headquarters to make a public protest.
Pours gasoline on public property and holds a lit torch in a dangerous manner, risking personal safety and potentially causing public harm.
Publicly demands truth about the deaths of 500 men, appeals for nationwide awareness.
Threatens to blow everyone up if approached; brandishes torch aggressively.
Refuses to back down despite threats, shows courage and commitment.
Expresses frustration and confusion at crowd’s antagonism.
Shouts demands for truth boldly and tries to use media coverage strategically to expose the issue.
Threatens to blow up himself and others rather than surrender, escalating the situation dangerously.
Holds his ground when attacked by the crowd and does not retreat despite provocations.
Runs crazily toward the crowd after being provoked, losing control and freezing suddenly.
Pushes Jezzie away and quickly dresses and packs, asserting control over his departure.
Refuses to take a call and initially avoids responsibility, showing evasiveness.
Immediately takes a call about important information, responds quickly, and arranges a meeting despite discomfort.
Listens attentively and with wide-eyed interest to Michael's story on the pier.
Responds with a brief, neutral comment 'Long time ago' to Michael's story.
Listens attentively and shows emotional reaction to Michael's story about the experiments and cruelty in Vietnam.
Listens intently and shows visible emotional reaction (shaking, puffy eyes) to harrowing war memories, indicating deep empathy and sincerity.
Rejects calming pills offered by Michael, possibly signifying an honest confrontation with trauma rather than avoidance.
Hesitates and shows discomfort when discussing the night of the offensive, revealing vulnerability and sincerity.
Struggles to recall important events about his unit's mission despite undergoing therapy; clearly shaken and hesitant to confront memories.
Engages in the conversation with Michael attentively, tries to piece together fragmented memories and understands the gravity of the situation.
Looks up from the trench and sees wave of American soldiers bearing down, shares confused moment with young attacker before being stabbed.
Struggles in chaos of battle but shows recognition and silent understanding in moment with enemy soldier.
Shivers and accepts Michael's jacket and company, showing vulnerability and allowing closeness.
Questions Michael's intentions suspiciously, showing guardedness and lack of immediate trust.
Engages in sincere conversation about shared traumatic experiences, expressing concern and seeking truth.
Questions Michael's motives and expresses skepticism about the situation.
Shows discomfort entering the sleazy hotel and adjusting to an unfamiliar environment.
Engages in a serious conversation, thoughtfully considering Michael's offer and the information about the antidote.
Shows fear and hesitation about taking the formula but ultimately complies with Michael's suggestion.
Asks for help and expresses vulnerability when he cannot move.
Initially hesitant to take the unknown formula but ultimately complies cautiously.
Tries to get up and calls for help after feeling immobilized and frightened.
Shows fear and lack of control when his surroundings literally fall apart and demonic forms appear.
Cries out for help when overwhelmed by demonic forces.
Fights the aid given by Michael (antidote), struggles but ultimately allows help.
Refuses to accept Michael's generous offer of credit cards and place to stay.
Welcomes Jezzie warmly by smiling and swinging her into the room.
Expresses love sincerely to Jezzie and shares intimate moments tenderly.
Smiles and allows Jezzie to initiate physical intimacy, showing comfort and affection.
Engages in a calm, loving interaction watching a romantic movie and listens to Jezzie's reflections.
Responds promptly and politely to the knock at the door, facilitating Jezzie's enjoyment of the dinner surprise.
Confidently declares intention to make love despite chaotic circumstances, showing decisiveness and emotional honesty.
Exhausted and begins to fall asleep while with Jezzie, showing vulnerability and lack of control over physical state.
Responds calmly to the knock at the door by quickly putting on a bathrobe and answering, demonstrating situational awareness and appropriate reaction.
Reassures Jezzie and shows affection despite difficult circumstances.
Refuses to let Jezzie accompany him citing concern for her safety.
Promises to send for Jezzie later, showing consideration and sincerity.
Uses Michael's credit card without explicit permission.
Yells angrily and calls someone a pervert when he discovers voyeurism through the stall hole.
Chases after the person who fled from the restroom.
Feels surprised and puzzled upon unexpectedly finding Michael's card in his pocket.
Pounds on Michael's door urgently and breaks it down to find him.
Frantically searches Michael's loft for signs of him, reacts with panic upon discovery of Michael's death.
Runs wildly and assaults a building out of grief and helplessness.
Smashes wildly at the door until the lock flies open to get inside.
Rushes into the dark loft, finds the light, and quickly surveys the scene.
Fumbles with lab bottles without understanding them; fails to recognize important clues.
Trips and falls over the body after discovering the severed head, showing panic and lack of composure.
Runs wildly and hurls himself against a building in panic and despair.
Greets the doorman warmly with a friendly greeting despite his battered condition.
Yanks the taxi door open and drags himself inside forcefully, ignoring the driver's reluctance.
Approaches and stops a speeding taxi in the dark, successfully convinces the driver to take him despite the driver's hesitation by using limited resources confidently.
Alters his appearance as he crosses the Brooklyn Bridge, suggesting a loss or change in himself, which shows internal struggle but not necessarily competence or incompetence in action.
Greets the doorman warmly and responds calmly to concern despite his battered condition, showing social ease and composure.
Steps into the street in front of a speeding taxi in an ambiguous way, possibly risking harm or failing to clearly signal intentions.
Gently opens door to family apartment, calls out to check on family.
Carries a photo of family with him through the apartment.
Clearly distressed and insistent on finding out what happened to his family.
Retrieves key hidden under carpet, uses it skillfully to enter apartment quietly and calls out for family.
Explores empty apartment systematically, checking rooms and familiar surroundings before reacting.
Shows surprise and disgust at own reflection, indicating emotional vulnerability but also awareness.
Approaches situation cautiously but then gets startled and nervous when confronted by Jezzie, fails to maintain composure.
Appears confused and fearful when confronted by Jezzie, tries to understand her behavior.
Shows confusion and fear when confronted with Jezzie's strange behavior and impossible movements, fails to understand what is happening to him.
Remains frozen and unable to act or respond effectively when Jezzie's verbal assault undermines his mental state.
Turns to confront the terror despite fear.
Whispers to himself that the terror isn't real, overwhelmed and confused.
Turns to confront the terror instead of fleeing immediately.
Is overwhelmed by confusion and fear, becomes rooted in fear and struggles to stand against the force.
Whispers to himself 'This isn't happening' showing denial instead of rational response to danger.
Looks up and yells for help despite his voice being lost, showing a moment of seeking assistance.
Despite terrifying, overwhelming chaos and fear, summons courage and steadfastly approaches and confronts the creature relentlessly.
Despite overwhelming fear and terrifying surroundings, Jacob takes a deep breath, forms resolve, and courageously moves toward the creature.
Withstands intense physical and psychological assault while clutching the creature, struggling defiantly and refusing to let go.
Stands motionless and unsure initially when hearing Louis's voice.
Buries the suffocating mask covering a tortured human face, which turns out to be his own, revealing a profound moment of self-recognition and pain.
Experiences and lets out a huge cry of devastating sadness upon realizing he is dead.
The flood of memories includes moments of joy and connection with others like Jezzie, Louis, Michael, Sarah, and family, indicating meaningful relationships and emotional depth.
Digs into the dark suffocating film and pulls off the mask to reveal his own dead face, showing presence of mind and confrontation of a disturbing reality.
Takes a moment to realize he is dead, displaying confusion and pain rather than immediate clear understanding.
Stares at his own dead face for a long time and cries out with devastating sadness, showing emotional vulnerability but not active problem-solving.
Approaches a mysterious presence with curiosity and calls out gently, showing openness and care.
Is moved to tears and embraces his son Gabe warmly and repeatedly, showing deep love and affection.
Listens carefully and notices the familiar music, showing curiosity and attentiveness.
Approaches cautiously when he hears the music and detects a presence in the shadows, exhibiting careful observation and awareness.
Responds emotionally to seeing his son, overwhelmed and moved to tears, which shows deep feeling but may impair rational action in the moment.
Calls out and attempts to connect with his son despite the uncertainty of the situation, showing initiative and emotional intelligence.
Sits down, stunned and motionless after the reunion, reflecting a moment of passivity after a significant emotional experience.
Smiles at his son Gabe and shares a moment of total euphoria with him as they ascend the stairs together.
Is overcome with emotion and sits down on the stairs, initially unable to follow his son.
Eventually follows his son up the stairs despite initial stunned reaction, smiles and shares a moment of euphoria with his son.
Claps hands warmly with old professor and smiles, expresses pleasure to see him.
Remains seated after class dismissal when others leave, indicating possible introspection or detachment.
Enters quietly and takes a seat attentively during the lecture.
Fingers pencil distractedly while listening.
Remains seated after sudden class dismissal while others leave.
Initiates greeting with Professor Stern and engages respectfully.
Identifies his job honestly and confidently as a mailman when asked.
Admits he hasn't seen his wife in months and is now with another woman.
Describes his new partner as a 'fiery lady' with a smile and coy tone.
Opens up to his professor about his personal life and struggles after Vietnam.
Explains his current job at the post office with a certain casual wit, indicating self-awareness and some intelligence.
Mentions he gave up on intellectual pursuits after Vietnam, feeling his brain 'too small' to comprehend the chaos, indicating a loss of confidence or mental retreat.
Dismisses the missed job opportunity due to a hiring freeze and the draft, showing awareness of external circumstances rather than personal failings.
Smiles coyly and deflects Stern's praise, showing modesty or possibly a lack of full confidence in his own mind.
Opens up hesitantly about seeing demons and asks Professor Stern for understanding and insight.
Rejects psychiatric help, emphasizing he wants sincere understanding rather than dismissal.
Admits to seeing demons and seeks out Professor Stern for insight rather than medical help.
Expresses awareness of how his claims might sound and resists easy dismissal by psychiatric explanations.
Turns to a knowledgeable figure for insight and admits his problem openly, showing a proactive but uncertain approach.
Admits to being afraid and asks for help sincerely.
Admits fear and confusion openly, asks the professor for help.
Persists in claiming he sees demons despite lack of scientific validation.
Does not reject scientific help but seems caught between belief and skepticism.
Shows tears of emotion when receiving praise from Stern, then hurriedly wipes them away.
Is mesmerized and terrified by the dancers' transformation, especially Jezzie, and tries to resist but is unable to break free.
Cries weakly for help while in delirium, showing vulnerability and a plea for assistance.
Becomes out of control and filled with fury that bursts into hysteria, displayed as spastic and delirious behavior.
Becomes spastic, delirious, and out of control, unable to manage his own fury or pain.
Cries weakly for help while suffering severe injuries, showing vulnerability and helplessness.
Turns up television sound to listen to interview, then immediately runs to the bathroom to urinate.
Turns down the television sound after returning from bathroom.
Stops on an interview program, turns up the sound, and runs to the bathroom promptly when needed.
Turns down the sound after returning from the bathroom, demonstrating attentiveness and control of the environment.
Gets startled and jumps when the telephone rings suddenly, then turns off the TV.
Engages intimately with Jezzie, showing emotional presence and attentiveness.
Stares silently at a blank phone screen before talking, indicating distraction or lack of focus.
Yells for help loudly when threatened by the demon image, showing vulnerability and the need for assistance.
Becomes obsessed and immobilized by fear in front of the demonic image, showing internal struggle but no outward aggression or coldness.
Allows Jezzie to comfort him by holding him while he is shaking and vulnerable.
Responds with a blank stare and does not communicate when Jezzie calls him.
Does not resist when restrained and injected in the hospital.
Attempts to sit up despite being forced down and drugged.
Remains silent and unresponsive when Jezzie calls him and holds a blank stare while shaking.
Lies curled up in a fetal position, shivering and needing comfort from Jezzie.
Barely struggles as he is forcibly injected with serum and restrained by orderlies.
Tries to scream but no sound comes out and attempts to sit up when wheeled through corridors, though he is forced back down.
Screams for help calling out to Jezzie, showing vulnerability and desire for connection.
Endures torment passively without retaliating or lashing out.
In bedroom, responds with tension and detachment to Jezzie's vacuuming, indicating emotional distance or withdrawal.
Attempts to sit up despite being drugged, showing some physical agency amid incapacitation.
Calls out to Jezzie for help in a moment of extreme fear and vulnerability.
Experiences hallucinogenic torment passively without apparent resistance or strategic response.
Perseveres through physical pain by doing back exercises despite mental drifting and discomfort.
Appears mentally distracted and physically unwell after days without proper care, indicating diminished capacity.
Yells and glares at Jezzie to keep her from touching the gasoline can, showing concern for safety.
Yells repeatedly to get Jezzie's attention and tries to communicate with her sincerely.
Accuses Jezzie harshly, calls her 'out of your fucking mind' and tells her to 'go to Hell'.
Shows suspicion and distrust by denying that he knows Jezzie despite living with her for two years.
Responds coldly and aggressively to Jezzie's anger, telling her to 'Go to Hell' and reacts with violence toward the ceiling demon projection.
Does not attempt to reconcile or show remorse despite Jezzie's emotional outburst and departure.
Responds to emotional turmoil by physically attacking the ceiling demon, showing quick defensive reaction and determination.
After destroying part of the ceiling, hesitates and intensely contemplates using gasoline and matches, showing momentary doubt or restraint.
Fights Michael when he tries to force the antidote down his throat, gags and tries to spit it out but is unable to.
Sits quietly beside Michael, does not interrupt or speak, allowing Michael space and respecting his silence.
Stares at Michael with awe and confusion but does not lash out or express hostility.
Does not engage with Jezzie immediately despite her invitation to lie next to her on the bed.
Snaps off the TV to avoid distressing news, appears tired and evasive in conversation.
Responds to Jezzie's concern with irritation and defensiveness.
Snaps off the TV abruptly when a distressing news report comes on.
Evasively avoids answering questions about his day and his plans to leave town.
Expresses fatigue and irritability but maintains control of his emotions.
Makes a concrete decision to leave town and has already arranged a ticket.
Tries to relax and give himself over to Jezzie's touch despite tension.
Backs away after Jezzie's aggressive bite, appearing angry and disturbed.
Does not retaliate physically after Jezzie's bite, instead retreats from the situation.
Ignores Jezzie's apology and attempts to help, chooses to leave abruptly.
Throws the chair aside and hurries away despite Jezzie's pleas.
Uses a key to quietly enter the apartment, calls out to family members with hope and care.
Walks through the empty apartment searching for his family, showing concern.
Tries to communicate gently with Jezzie and demands answers about his family despite nervousness.
Throws a chair to block an attacker and quickly escapes the apartment.
Retrieves a hidden key from under the hallway carpet to enter an apartment quietly.
Explores the empty apartment methodically, checking each room to find his family.
Confronts Jezzie calmly despite being startled by her imposing presence.
Appears nervous and confused about the whereabouts of his family when questioned by Jezzie.
Reacts with fear and horror to Jezzie's menacing transformation and insults.
Tries to back away and run when confronted by Jezzie but his body betrays him and his legs barely move.
Attempts to understand and respond to a bizarre and terrifying situation, but appears overwhelmed and unable to act effectively.
Screams in terror and demands to know the identity of a terrifying demonic presence.
Faces a horrifying, grotesque transformation of Jezzie with intense rage but without backing down.
Confronts a terrifying, powerful demon without fleeing; his face shows intense rage and transformation rather than fear.
Yells at the demon with all his might, channeling the full fury of the Ladder inside him in a decisive moment.
Fiercely battles the DEMON with determination to protect or save something (his soul), showing intense commitment and resilience.
Reacting with animalistic fury and violence toward the DEMON, inflicting pain and destruction.
Holds down the stinging INSECT despite pain, demonstrating endurance and willingness to face suffering.
Creates or holds a new CHILD body formed from the fight, suggesting a protective or nurturing role emerging.
Fights the demon with overwhelming power and relentless determination, adapting to its transformations and continuing to hold on despite injury.
Initially shocked when the demon shrinks and changes shape, struggling to contain the new form.
Holds on tightly to his son despite the son's pleas to let go, showing a desperate but harsh behavior.
Reacts with horror and terror at his son's changing identity, recoiling from his own image.
Ultimately lets go after the 'voice' shocks him, indicating a moment of release and recognition.
Screams and struggles in pain as the flames follow and injure him, showing vulnerability and emotional anguish.
Throws his hands up in total submission and surrender to forces beyond himself while suffering extreme pain.
Screams in pain and calls for help amidst a deadly fire, running frantically trying to escape.
Stops running and surrenders completely to overwhelming forces beyond his control, sitting motionless within the flames.
Remains conscious and aware even after being completely burned, showing unusual mental resilience.
Stares with awe and wonder as he transforms into a radiant being of light, showing openness and receptivity.
Begins to stir and stand up despite weakness and frailty, showing determination and gradual regaining of strength.
Initially stares with awe and disbelief at Michael's presence, showing hesitation and uncertainty.
Responds to Michael's encouragement and instruction by nodding and taking a huge breath, preparing himself to transform.
Watches the celestial stairway with awe and allows himself to be absorbed by the light without resistance.
